channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Cairo Journal: Coffee, Bikini Waxes, X-Rays: Almost Anything Can Be Sent to Homes in Cairo
item.media:description: Islam Sabry delivered specialty bread last week in Cairo. Here, almost anything can be delivered to consumers’ homes.
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.description: Given the Egyptian capital’s bad traffic and long, hot summers, plus the meager cost of deliveries, city residents need little encouragement to pick up the phone.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: A Powerful Russian Weapon: The Spread of False Stories
item.media:description: Unidentified soldiers overran Crimea in March 2014. Russia reclaimed the territory from Ukraine, and President Vladimir V. Putin later admitted that the troops were Russian special forces.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Using both conventional media and covert channels, the Kremlin relies on disinformation to create doubt, fear and discord in Europe and the United States.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Lightning Strike Kills More Than 300 Reindeer in Norway
item.description: “We have never seen anything like this,” said an official from the Norwegian Environment Agency, after an entire herd appeared to have been electrocuted.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL

item.title: Greece Cracks Down on ‘Triangle of Corruption’ in TV
item.media:description: Greeks watching television coverage of a rally last July in a cafe in Athens. The government opened TV broadcasting to unregulated private entities in the 1980s.
item.description: The leftist government plans to auction off four new TV licenses on Tuesday, spurring a sharp debate and struggle for media power.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Juan Gabriel’s Death, Like His Music, Brings Mexicans Together
item.media:description: Fans and performers gathered in Mexico City on Sunday at a statue of Juan Gabriel, a beloved singer who died at 66.
item.description: Across Mexico, fans mourned and celebrated the singer who for years provided the soundtrack for their joyous occasions and their heartbreaks.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Dilma Rousseff of Brazil Says She Won’t Be Silenced in Impeachment Trial
item.description: The suspended president took the stand and fiercely argued that she was innocent of the charges of manipulating the federal budget.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: A Reporter Recalls One of the Many Victims of Colombia’s War: Her Father
item.media:description: Members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, in the mountains of Colombia this month.
item.description: In 1999, Jaime Correal Martinz was captured and held for eight months. The ordeal cost him everything, but before he died in June he hoped for peace.
item.dc:creator: ANNIE CORREAL

item.title: An Epidemic of ‘Dead Eyes’ in Kashmir as India Uses Pellet Guns on Protesters
item.media:description: Kashmiri doctors and paramedics, their eyes covered by patches, protested at a hospital in Srinagar on Aug. 10. They sought to evoke the plight of victims of pellet guns fired by Indian security forces to disperse crowds.
item.description: The nonlethal weapon employed by Indian security forces to disperse crowds since early July can cause ghastly damage, often blinding victims, some of them children.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: 3 Suspects in 2009 Attack on Sri Lankan Cricket Team Are Killed in Pakistan
item.media:description: Pakistani police officers prayed for one of their colleagues who was killed during an attack on Sri Lankan cricket players in Lahore, in 2009.
item.description: The police said the men, and a fourth militant, had died in a shootout when another group of militants tried to free them from custody.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Once a Qaeda Recruiter, Now a Voice Against Jihad
item.description: In a new effort to counter the lure of terrorism, a former American jihadist is moving into the public sphere to research the ideology he once spread.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Arson Attack Damages Crime Lab in Brussels
item.media:description: Damage caused to the National Institute of Criminalistics and Criminology in Belgium on Monday.
item.description: No one was wounded, but the destruction was described as severe, and evidence crucial to terrorism investigations may have been damaged.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER

item.title: With Uzbekistan’s Ruler Gravely Ill, Questions Arise on Succession
item.media:description: President Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan in April.
item.description: President Islam Karimov wields sweeping powers, and if a transition is necessary, any discord over his successor may destabilize the Central Asian country.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Man Thought to Be China’s Jack the Ripper Is Arrested
item.media:description: The courtyard of Gao Chengyong’s family home in Lanzhou, China. He is suspected in nine deaths in the city of Baiyin and two in Inner Mongolia.
item.description: Gao Chengyong is suspected of raping and killing 11 people over 14 years, sometimes cutting off body parts and slitting their throats.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere: ‘Facekini’-Wearing Chinese Stand Up for the Right to Bare Nothing
item.media:description: Chinese women in facekinis enjoying an afternoon at the No. 1 Bathing Beach in the northern city of Qingdao.
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.description: Chinese women who cover their heads sometimes also wear bathing suits over their entire torsos and arms, similar to the burkini and to surfers’ wet suits.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Suicide Attack Kills Scores of Military Recruits in Aden, Yemen
item.media:description: The scene of the car bombing in Aden, Yemen, on Monday. The Islamic State called the attack a “martyrdom operation,” and it said that “around 60 people” had been killed.
item.description: The Islamic State called the car bombing, in the crowded Mansoura neighborhood, a “martyrdom operation.”
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF and SAEED AL-BATATI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Australian Aid Worker Who Was Abducted in Afghanistan Is Released
item.description: Kerry Jane Wilson, who is in her 60s, had been working in the country for about 20 years when she was taken from her office in Jalalabad on April 28.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: In Syria, Rebels Threaten Kurdish-Controlled Territory as U.S. Allies Clash
item.media:description: Turkish tanks on Saturday driving from Karkamis, Turkey, across the border into Syria.
item.description: Aided by Turkish airstrikes, Syrian rebels pressed deeper into the northern part of the country, putting two American-backed forces in conflict.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Juan Gabriel, a Pop Music ‘Icon’ in Mexico, Dies at 66
item.media:description: Juan Gabriel in 1980.
item.description: A prolific singer and songwriter, he was nominated for six Grammys and received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Benjamin Ben-Eliezer, Former Israeli Defense Minister, Dies at 80
item.media:description: Benjamin Ben-Eliezer in 2002.
item.description: Mr. Ben-Eliezer, who was born in Iraq, served in the military for 30 years, held senior positions in government and was close to Arab leaders.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Israel Joins Bikini Fray, Ordering Concert Singer to Cover Up
item.media:description: Bikinis are a matter of routine on Tel Aviv beaches although each section of coastline reveals a different facet of the city.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: In a twist on the French debate over the full-body burkini worn by some Muslim women, Israel is insisting on modest dress by performers at government-sponsored events.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Singapore Confirms 41 Cases of Locally Transmitted Zika Virus
item.media:description: A worker sprayed the corridor of a public housing estate near where a locally transmitted Zika virus case was discovered in Singapore on Monday.
item.description: Most of those infected are foreign construction workers, and all but seven have fully recovered, the Health Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Iran Arrests Person Linked to Negotiations on Nuclear Deal
item.description: The disclosure appeared to be the latest sign of the Iranian leadership’s frustration over the deal, which has failed to yield significant economic benefits.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: What in the World: If You Miss a Train in France, You May Catch a Tune Instead
item.media:description: A teenager playing the piano at Gare du Nord train station in Paris this month.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: About 100 pianos sit in train stations across France, free for anyone to sit and play, and travelers from all walks of life have taken to doing just that.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)

item.title: What in the World: Shh. It’s Naptime at Ikea in China.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: At Ikea’s 21 stores in China, shoppers (and those simply looking for climate-controlled shut-eye) have no qualms about getting comfortable on the display furniture.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Will Anyone Save Venice Before It’s Too Late?
item.description: Tourism threatens to destroy one of Italy’s most historic cities. The United Nations has issued a stern warning.
item.dc:creator: SALVATORE SETTIS
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Opinion: Why I Go to Aleppo
item.media:description: Medics treated a man injured by a barrel bomb explosion in eastern Aleppo, on July 16.
item.description: The field hospital is often overwhelmed. We can’t save everyone. We can only try.
item.dc:creator: SAMER ATTAR

item.title: Opinion: At the Beach in My Burkini
item.description: I dreaded wearing it in middle school. Not anymore.
item.dc:creator: ROMAISSAA BENZIZOUNE

item.title: Photo Editors’ Notebook: What Makes the Image of Omran Daqneesh Extraordinary?
item.media:description: The front page of The New York Times on August 19 featured a photograph by Mahmoud Raslan of a 5-year-old boy who was rescued after an airstrike in Aleppo, Syria.
item.description: “It’s a difficult question for even the most seasoned photo editor to answer.”
item.dc:creator: CRAIG ALLEN

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
